ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Misophonia
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Patient exhibits intense emotional reactions (anger, crying) and avoidance behaviors to specific trigger sounds (chewing, breathing) produced by parents.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Tinnitus
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Chronic bilateral tinnitus present since age 8, described as painfully loud in quiet environments, with moderate quality of life impact (THI 54).

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Annoyance Hyperacusis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Slightly reduced Loudness Discomfort Levels (85-100 dB HL) at 2 and 4 kHz suggest a component of decreased sound tolerance alongside misophonia.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Hashimoto Thyroiditis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Co-occurring autoimmune condition which may contribute to fatigue, depression, and exacerbation of auditory symptoms.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Assess integrity of the acoustic reflex arc.
Evaluate hearing sensitivity in ultra-high frequencies (9-20 kHz).
Determine sound tolerance levels for tones and speech.
Quantify the severity and impact of tinnitus and sound sensitivity (THI, TFI).

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Initial evaluation by the referring otolaryngologist demonstrated normal peripheral hearing sensitivity and middle ear function. However, an asymmetry was noted in acoustic reflexes, which were absent in the left ear despite normal hearing.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Normal hearing sensitivity (0-10 dB HL) from 250 to 8,000 Hz bilaterally.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRT 15 dB HL AU; WRS 100% at 50 dB HL AU.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Ipsilateral reflexes present in the right ear but absent in the left ear.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Comprehensive assessment at the university clinic confirmed normal hearing through ultra-high frequencies. Testing revealed slightly reduced sound tolerance at specific frequencies and a moderate to severe subjective impact from tinnitus and misophonia.

tests.name: High-frequency audiometry
tests.result_summary: Normal thresholds (better than 15 dB HL) from 9,000 to 20,000 Hz bilaterally.

tests.name: Loudness Discomfort Levels (LDLs)
tests.result_summary: 85-100 dB HL for tones (slightly reduced at 2 and 4 kHz); 100 dB HL for speech.

tests.name: Self-Report Scales
tests.result_summary: THI 54/100; TFI 60/100; Subjective severity 9/10, annoyance 9/10, QoL impact 7/10.

proposed_items: Sound therapy using smartphone apps (relaxing sounds, broadband noise) via personal earphones
Multidisciplinary approach including psychology/CBT for misophonia and anxiety
counseling_actions: Directive counseling to reclassify tinnitus as a neutral stimulus
Education regarding misophonia (conditioned emotional response) versus hyperacusis
Discussion of the impact of stress and autoimmune health (Hashimoto's) on symptoms
Recommendation to avoid silence and use sound enrichment to reduce contrast of trigger sounds

escalation.rationale_short: Referral indicated to address anxiety/depression and provide cognitive behavioral strategies for misophonia triggers.

follow_up_plan.timeline: Every 3 months for up to 18 months; audiometric re-evaluation at 6 months
follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor for tinnitus habituation and changes in sound sensitivity.
